subject: Remove warnings for long vgs and lvs calls
commit_message:
Remove warnings for long vgs and lvs calls

We put some warning statements in a while back for
lvs and vgs commands that lasted more than 60 seconds
so we could easily query issues in the gate.

Since then we've made a number of changes to improve our
LVM interactions including the use of an LVM conf file with
a filter for only the VG's Cinder uses.

There's one issue remaining however where during the instance
rescue test in Nova where LVM get's stuck trying to open
devices that no longer exist.  Part of this I think is due
to some manipulation that Nova/KVM does on the attached volume
when the test is run, but also the rescue process in Nova
uses LVM volumes as well and does some moving around and mounting
of devices.

The result is that LVM calls can take quite a while
(greater than 100 seconds) to complete during the rescue process.
This doesn't result in any failures, just that the rescue process
slows things down dramatically and is a pretty heavy process.

Also, the newer versions of process utils include completion
timing in the logs so we don't really need this any longer eve
to query timings and get info.

This patch removes those log statements, and proposes we
document somewhere that rescue operations on a setup that
includes c-vol service and nova-compute service on the same
node will temporarily impact LVM performance.

Change-Id: Iddc8318ba23725990512f5a5945406561818c5ba

subject: Set instance host and node on finish_migration
commit_message:
Set instance host and node on finish_migration

Currently, for cold migration, there is a presumption of success unlike
live migration. The instance's host and node fields are updated to the
destination host after the disk and network are migrated to the
destination, but before the images are fetched from glance and applied
(in finish_migration). This makes it impossible to do a fallback to
copy from the source host if the needed image isn't found in glance,
as the source host has already been blown away on the instance, when
migration isn't actually finished yet.

This change moves the assignment of instance host and node to the
finish_migration step, after images have been fetched and applied,
when migration is actually finished.

subject: Use case insensitive dict for Resource attributes
commit_message:
Use case insensitive dict for Resource attributes

Any resources which work with headers - mostly Container and Object in
object_store - are not currently working properly due to the case
sensitive nature of the attributes being in a traditional dictionary.
Any header props *set* on those resources which are then sent to the
server are ok, which is why we've been able to set and then receive our
own values,  but any that are received would have to be in the matching
case that the prop is setup as. This is not generally the case, as
setting metadata on containers or objects in Horizon or other control
panels uses capitalization, which ends up not matching up properly when
we convert the server values into a resource.

This change implements a CaseInsensitiveDict which keeps the original
user-set values around and then keeps a dictionary mapping a lowercased
version of the key to the user-set key. It implements the typical
MutableMapping operations.

subject: Allow lists and strings for Json parameters via provider resources
commit_message:
Allow lists and strings for Json parameters via provider resources

Currently we have a somewhat bogus internal equivalence between the
"json" parameter type and the MAP property type.  This is a problem
when exposing json parameters via provider resources, because the
schema of the exposed property does not exactly match the capabilities
of the underlying parameter.

Specifically, json parameters can take strings (json serialized list or
map), and also lists and maps directly.  Currently, we can only pass
maps, which means some data, for example a list of maps (which is possible
when interacting directly with a json parameter) is not possible when
using the same parameter abstracted via a TemplateResource.

To work around this add a flag which relaxes the type rules and enables
some coercion of map values, only when they're going via a schema derived
from a json parameter.

Having DATABASE_QUERY_LOGGING enabled results in devstack turning
on verbose mysql query logging. This results in a log file

subject: WIP: Ensure a cluster is only ever managed by a single Nova compute
commit_message:
WIP: Ensure a cluster is only ever managed by a single Nova compute

This is a proposed fix for:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1419785

The above happens when you configure 2 HA nodes with different
hostnames to manage the same cluster. On failover, badness ensues when
the incorrectly hostnamed standby tries to take over.

It would be nice to fix the badness, however it is currently very
deeply engrained in Nova. Lots of things assume a consistent 'host',
and they will all be broken in this scenario. Instead, this patch
detects a change of Nova compute, and rejects it.

During the driver's init_host it checks all managed clusters for the
custom value 'openstack_compute_host'. If the value is not present, it
sets it to the current host. If it is, it checks it against the
current hostname. It will raise an Exception if any non-matching
values are found, which in turn will cause Nova to fail to start.

Make GetOrHeadHandler take an optional chunk size.

If given the chunk size, chunks are yielded to the client in exactly

will be buffered until there's a full chunk.

This is good for EC because we can set this to the size of a fragment,
then instantiate a bunch of these things and read one chunk from each,
then decode and send it on up the line.

subject: libvirt: proper monitoring of live migration progress
commit_message:
libvirt: proper monitoring of live migration progress

The current live migration code simply invokes migrateToURI
and waits for it to finish, or raise an exception. It considers
all exceptions to mean the live migration aborted and the VM is
still running on the source host. This is totally bogus, as there
are a number of reasons why an error could be raised from the
migrateToURI call. There are at least 5 different scenarios for
what the VM might be doing on source + dest host upon error.
The migration might even still be going on, even if after the
error has occurred.

A more reliable way to deal with this is to actively query
libvirt for the domain job status. This gives an indication
of whether the job is completed, failed or cancelled. Even
with that though, there is a need for a few heuristics to
distinguish some of the possible error scenarios.

This change to do active monitoring of the live migration process
also opens the door for being able to tune live migration on the
fly to adjust max downtime or bandwidth to improve chances of
getting convergence, or to automatically abort it after too much
time has elapsed instead of letting it carry on until the end of
the universe. This change merely records memory transfer progress
and leaves tuning improvements to a later date.

Closes-bug: #1414065

subject: Log a warning when deprecated opts are used
commit_message:
Log a warning when deprecated opts are used

This change logs the warning at lookup time instead of parse time
because we have no way of knowing at parse time which options are
deprecated.  It does use a set to make sure it only logs a given
deprecation warning once per option so it won't spam the logs.

I could not find a way to log deprecations for cli args.  argparse
seems to only write the value to the undeprecated name, so there's
no way to tell whether it came from a deprecated name originally.
Since most of our opts are set through config files I don't see
this as a huge issue though.

I'm also not using the warnings module because its deprecation
mechanisms seem more developer focused, and for config opts we
need to notify the user.  This is not possible with the warnings
module in Python 2.6 (there's no way to send warnings to the log
by default), and since we still need to support that for oslo libs
I went with a simple logged warning instead.

Change-Id: I4580831f34c48882fb07288fa8d55272b58e2674
Closes-Bug: 1390408

subject: ganesha utils: allow remote execution as root
commit_message:
ganesha utils: allow remote execution as root

Remote execute calls in the ganesha helpers are made using ganesha
utils's SSHExecutor object that uses  processutils's ssh_execute()
method. But processutils's ssh_execute() method unlike processutils's
execute() method does not accept an argument whose identifier is
'run_as_root=', necessary to execute commands with super user
privilege. So allow 'run as root' behavior in remote execution by
prepending 'sudo' to the command passed to processutils's ssh_execute()
method, in the SSHExecutor's __call__() method.

Change-Id: I3c9f9837b692b06bad15341d09ce5b7c4dfa7268
